speaker: Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series
text: Victor Garber  * * *  ## Transcript {Mike Lee}

speaker: Skyline
text: a heavy construction crane lifts a load above the skyscrapers.  _ACT ONE  Scene One - Caf e Nervosa FADE IN. Frasier is sitting at table reading the newspaper when Roz comes in. _
prevSpeaker: Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh hi, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, checking out the personal ads, huh?

speaker: Frasier
text: Actually, I'm looking at the want ads.  I'm trying to find a housekeeper.  Now that Daphne is Niles's girlfriend, it doesn't feel right to ask her to pick up after me anymore, so-

speaker: Roz
text: Mmm.

speaker: Frasier
text: Awfully difficult finding someone, though.

speaker: Roz
text: It's hard getting what you want these days, isn't it?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_a little wary_] Indeed.

speaker: Roz
text: But you can still find convenience and value, if you know where to look-

speaker: Frasier
text: Dear God, what are you selling?

speaker: Roz
text: [_produces a sample book of_] Wrapping paper!  It's a fundraiser for Alice's school.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, at least it's a worthy cause.

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, let's have a look. [_looks_] Oh, that one's too garish... eh, don't like this one, either... ooh, I'm certainly not crazy about bunnies...

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, give me that! [_takes the book_] You're getting five rolls of "Peace on Earth" and thanks for your support!

speaker: Niles
text: _Machiatto_... make it a _doup-iato._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!  Niles please, whatever's wrong, the answer doesn't lie at the bottom of an espresso cup.

speaker: Niles
text: It's Mel again.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, lord.  Still making you humiliate yourself at social functions while she plays the long-suffering wife?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm afraid so.  But she said a couple more weeks, and I'll have my divorce.

speaker: Frasier
text: She said that two weeks ago!  What was it this time?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, we attended Colonel Turner's very large, very High Episcopalian funeral, during the course of which my cell phone rang repeatedly.  I was not allowed to answer it, and Mel had set the ringer on "La Cucaracha."

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Niles, I'm so sorry.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, it's all right.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I called you twice.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I ruined quite a sendoff, with an honor guard, the colonel's butler seating people, _two_ archbishops-

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me, did you just say "butler?"

speaker: Niles
text: Oh yes, I know, an-an honest-to-goodness English butler. The colonel was a bit of an anachronism.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, yes.  That's amusing. [_they chuckle_] I suppose this butler saw to the colonel's every need.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, oh - clipped his cigars, poured his scotch...

speaker: Frasier
text: Laid out his clothes for him, and served him his meals... _Inspiration hits them together.  They stop talking and grab for their cell phones._

speaker: Niles
text: I saw him first!

speaker: Frasier
text: You've had a gardener and a maid!

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, but never a butler!

speaker: Frasier
text: But it's my turn!

speaker: Niles
text: But it's my dream!

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne won't have to clean anymore!

speaker: Niles
text: I tip my cap, sir.  _Frasier smiles and dials his phone.  And we:  FADE OUT  Scene Two -- Apartment - Morning FADE IN. Frasier is asleep in his bedroom, with a mask over his eyes.  Ferguson, an English butler of about fifty, comes into the room with a serving tray and opens the curtains, letting light in.  He then takes a bottle of cologne and squirts a fine puff over Frasier's head. As it settles on his face, Frasier wakes up._

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, Ferguson.  Is it morning already?

speaker: Ferguson
text: Indeed, sir.  I trust you slept well?

speaker: Frasier
text: Best sleep I've had in years.

speaker: Ferguson
text: Excellent.  Your coffee, sir.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_takes it_] Thank you.  To think I was skeptical when you said these pillows could be better arranged.

speaker: Ferguson
text: Yes, preparing a suitable sleeping environment is one of the first tasks I learned at my father's knee.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, your father also "butled?"

speaker: Ferguson
text: Oh yes, sir.  Even my father's father was a gentleman's gentleman.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_laughs_] Oh, that's a good one, Ferguson.

speaker: Ferguson
text: Thank you, sir, it's one of my staples.  Will it be breakfast

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I believe I'll join the rest of the household.

speaker: Ferguson
text: Very good, sir.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Ferguson.  Ah, you spoil me.  Keep it up.  _CUT TO:  Frasier's Living Room: Daphne and Martin are eating breakfast in their bathrobes.  The table is now covered by a fine lace cloth and set with elegant silverware. Frasier comes out._

speaker: Frasier
text: Morning, Dad, Daphne.

speaker: Martin/Daphne
text: Fras./Morning.

speaker: Martin
text: Where's Lord Weirdo?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, his name is Ferguson.

speaker: Ferguson
text: Good morning, Dr. Crane's residence.  Oh, good morning, Dr. Crane.  Oh, thank you, sir, your phone manner is also delightful. [_gives it to Daphne_] It's Dr. Crane for you, miss.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, thank you. [_gets up; into phone_] Hello, Niles.  Oh, yes!

speaker: Frasier
text: Dear God!

speaker: Martin
text: What's wrong?

speaker: Frasier
text: That politicking Alan Murchie has just been elected president of the opera board!

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I'll never forget where I was when I heard the news.

speaker: Frasier
text: This pinhead is president, I can't even get on the board!

speaker: Ferguson
text: And what will you be sending to congratulate Mr. Murchie, sir?

speaker: Frasier
text: Curses and epithets is all he'll get from me!

speaker: Ferguson
text: Quite right.  However, a well-chosen gift might draw the eye of Mr. Murchie as he considers a replacement for his now- vacant seat on the board.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, if it'll make you happy, Ferguson, let's send him a bottle of Chateau Belle Veux.

speaker: Ferguson
text: If I may, sir, I'm overheard Mr. Murchie speak fondly of the family villa in Umbria.  He may consider a wine from that region especially thoughtful.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's a little on the nose, but fine.  _Reset to Kitchen: Ferguson comes in to put breakfast away just as Daphne is finishing._

speaker: Daphne
text: I love you, too.  Bye. [_hangs up_]

speaker: Ferguson
text: Manchester, right?

speaker: Daphne
text: Is it that obvious?

speaker: Ferguson
text: To me it is.  My mum's from Manchester.  Used to scream her lungs out for United.

speaker: Daphne
text: Is that so?  My Uncle Jack once tried to get Bobby Charlton's autograph, until Bobby cracked him over the head with a can of lager.  Twelve stitches, and he still has the can!  Here, let me give you a hand tidying up.

speaker: Ferguson
text: Oh, thank you, miss.

speaker: Daphne
text: You know, you needn't stand on ceremony for Dr. Crane's father.  He prefers it if you're more informal.

speaker: Ferguson
text: Oh, it's rather difficult for me.  I'm accustomed to formality. _Ferguson takes a fruit basket on the stove and begins polishing the apples._

speaker: Ferguson
text: Besides, I find it's more professional.  It helps draw the line between a family and its servant.

speaker: Daphne
text: Are you referring to Niles and me?

speaker: Ferguson
text: Oh, that's none of my business.

speaker: Daphne
text: No, it's all right.  We're together.  He told me he'd been in love with me for seven years, and [_giggles_] I couldn't help but fall head over heels.  It's like a fairy tale.

speaker: Ferguson
text: Seven years?  He sounds shy.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, he is.  He was also married for much of the time.

speaker: Ferguson
text: Mm... but now your prince is free.

speaker: Daphne
text: Almost.  He married someone else.

speaker: Ferguson
text: I see.

speaker: Daphne
text: No, you don't understand.  Once that divorce goes through, we'll be together forever.

speaker: Ferguson
text: Well, I hope it's moving swiftly through the course.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, he hasn't filed yet. _The ridiculousness of what she's saying is gradually becoming as clear to her as it is to him._

speaker: Daphne
text: But when his wife thinks the time is right, which is soon, he will.  Well, not that she's in charge of us... [_flustered_] Oh look, I'm giving you the wrong impression-

speaker: Ferguson
text: Miss Moon, please understand that this is not meant to be cruel.  But I've witnessed much heartbreak in my career, and I've come to know that an employee-employer romance has little chance of success.  The status relationship will always exist.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, thank goodness I'm not as cynical as you are!  True love is stronger than status.  I don't care what anyone says or thinks, Niles and I are in love. [_turns to go, then_] And don't spread that around, it's a secret.  _Ferguson smiles.  FADE TO:  Scene Three - Apartment FADE IN. Martin is watching TV in his Armchair, hoisting a beer in one hand and a sandwich in the other.  Ferguson stands beside him with the remote. There are the sounds of horses whinnying._

speaker: Martin
text: Next.

speaker: Martin
text: Next.

speaker: Martin
text: Next.

speaker: Martin
text: Ooh, Shark Week!  At ease.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good day, all!

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Fras!  How'd your lunch go with that opera guy?

speaker: Frasier
text: Excellent!  Not only did Murchie rave on and on about the bottle of Umbrian wine I sent, but he intimated that I was "Opera Board timber!" [_chuckles_] Now all I have to do is continue on my charm-offensive with the other board members.

speaker: Ferguson
text: Then might I suggest a party, sir?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I'm way ahead of you this time.  I was thinking of a little post-opera soiree next week after the opening of

speaker: Ferguson
text: If I may take the liberty, sir, perhaps holding the party prior to the opera might be easier on the older guests.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's good thinking.  Yes, yes, it's a very nice spin on my initial, uh... insight of the party.

speaker: Ferguson
text: You flatter me, sir.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Frasier.  Ah yes, Ferguson!

speaker: Ferguson
text: How do you do, sir?

speaker: Niles
text: Very well.

speaker: Ferguson
text: May I take your coat, sir?

speaker: Niles
text: Certainly. _As Ferguson takes his coat, Niles and Frasier share a look, like boys over a thrilling toy._

speaker: Ferguson
text: Sherry, Dr. Crane?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, thank you, Ferguson, but even as we speak I have a bottle of Veuve Clicquot chilling in my apartment, and you know the old caution: "champagne after sherry makes tummy grow wary."

speaker: Ferguson
text: You have your brother's wit, sir.

speaker: Frasier
text: So Niles, you're awfully chipper today.

speaker: Niles
text: And why not?  Daphne and I are going out on a date!

speaker: Frasier
text: Wha-?  Niles, what if somebody sees you and reports back to Mel?

speaker: Niles
text: Mel be damned!  Daphne and I are going to have a romantic evening together at _my_ apartment - not only that, she's going in _my_ car, in _my_ backseat, under a pile of _my_ coats and blankets!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, cell phone.

speaker: Ferguson
text: Shall I?

speaker: Niles
text: Can he?

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh, would you?

speaker: Ferguson
text: [_answering_] Dr. Crane's line. _Niles mouths, "I love that!" to Frasier.  Daphne comes out in an evening dress._

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm ready.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh Daphne, you look ravishing.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_giggles_] Oh, thank you.

speaker: Ferguson
text: It's Mrs. Crane, sir.

speaker: Niles
text: [_taking the phone_] Hello, Mel.  What?  Wait a minute, I thought we agreed twenty-four hours' notice, you can't just... all right, fine.  I'll see you then.

speaker: Frasier
text: Everything all right, Niles?

speaker: Niles
text: It's Mel, she's having tea with her sorority sisters and would like me to show up - late, of course, and preferably boorish.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, for Pete's sake, I thought this was supposed to be over by now.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes well, so did I, but as Mel so politely reminded me, if I want this divorce to be quick and simple, I have to dance to her tune.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sorry.  You understand, don't you?

speaker: Daphne
text: I guess so.

speaker: Niles
text: That's my girl. [_kisses her cheek_] I will make this up to you, I promise.

speaker: Daphne
text: You better get going.

speaker: Daphne
text: You heard, didn't you?

speaker: Daphne
text: No, I don't need that!  I mean, I know he loves me... and it took him seven years to tell me.  His ex-wife walked all over him, and now Mel's doing the same thing! What, is it going to take another seven years before he stands up for himself, or for us?

speaker: Ferguson
text: Why do you suppose he hasn't?

speaker: Daphne
text: I don't know.  For the first time I'm beginning to wonder if... if maybe there are too many differences.  Maybe he feels he has too much to lose.  Oh God, Ferguson, maybe you were right.  _She breaks down sobbing.  Ferguson, with his usual prescience, spreads his handkerchief on his lapel just as she bows over and cries on his shoulder.  He puts his arm around her.  END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO_  **WHAT THE BUTLER SAW**  _Scene Four - Apartment FADE IN. The Apartment is now decorated for Frasier's party.  A tasteful easy chair stands in place of Martin's Armchair.  As Ferguson pops champagne, Frasier comes out in his tuxedo._

speaker: Ferguson
text: I hope everything meets with your approval, sir.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh yes, indeed, indeed. [_notices_] Where's Dad's chair?

speaker: Ferguson
text: I took the liberty of removing it for the party.

speaker: Frasier
text: But Dad'll be furious!  And I completely forgot: he'll be here!  Swigging from a can and guessing women's weight, I'll be blackballed!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Dad, uh, listen, about tonight-

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, yeah, I'd love to hobnob and whatnot, but the Towncar's waiting to take me to the game.  Thanks for the tickets, Fras. [_clears throat_] Fergie? _Martin holds out his arms.  Ferguson places a paper bag in one hand, and a giant foam "We're #1!" hand (with extended index finger) in the other._

speaker: Ferguson
text: Your meatloaf sandwich, sir, and your finger.

speaker: Ferguson
text: I hope you don't mind, sir.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_still surprised_] Not at all.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ferguson, positions.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Niles, what are you doing here?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh Frasier, don't panic, I'm not crashing your party. I'm here to pick up Daphne.  We're going to the mall.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?  Well, no chance of running into Mel there.

speaker: Niles
text: It should be a night to remember.  We're going someplace called "the Limited."

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne!  Why aren't you dressed?

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm not sure if I'm up to going out tonight.  I really hate all this sneaking around.

speaker: Niles
text: It's not sneaking around!  We're going to be out in public, at the Tacoma Mall!  But the most important thing is, we'll be together.

speaker: Daphne
text: All right, I suppose that really is what matters.

speaker: Niles
text: All right, now tell me again, what are we going to eat?

speaker: Daphne
text: Curly fries!

speaker: Niles
text: Ooh...

speaker: Ferguson
text: Good evening, and welcome to the home of Dr. Frasier-

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh save it, it's just Roz. [_Roz is not flattered_] What are you doing here?

speaker: Roz
text: [_holds up boxes_] Um, your gift-wrapping came in.

speaker: Frasier
text: I thought I just ordered a few rolls!

speaker: Roz
text: You were more generous than you thought.

speaker: Ferguson
text: I'll put it in your room, sir.

speaker: Roz
text: You look like a gift-giver-

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, you put it in my room, he's working! _As he hustles her away, the doorbell rings a third time.  Ferguson opens the door to Alan Murchie, his wife Diane, and Mr. Worth, a man in his sixties._

speaker: Frasier
text: Alan Murchie, lovely to see you!

speaker: Murchie
text: [_shaking hands_] Likewise.  I don't think you've met my wife, Diane.

speaker: Frasier
text: _Enchant e._

speaker: Murchie
text: And this is Henry Worth, another board member.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, Henry, lovely to meet you.

speaker: Ferguson
text: May I take your coats?

speaker: Murchie
text: Oh, thank you.

speaker: Diane
text: Frasier, isn't that the colonel's old butler?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, Ferguson.  My sense of duty compelled me to take him in after the colonel passed.

speaker: Murchie
text: [_amused_] Yes, we felt the same sense of duty toward his art collection.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_laughs nervously_] Oh, that's very droll...

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me.

speaker: Roz
text: ...collection.  And the family pack really is your best value-

speaker: Frasier
text: [_grabs her_] Roz, what are you doing out here?  I'm sure Mr. Worth isn't interested in gift-wrapping.

speaker: Worth
text: Nonsense, she's delightful.  Now, what kind of deal would you give me if I bought a hundred rolls?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, I'd take off twenty percent.

speaker: Worth
text: And what would you take off if I bought five thousand rolls?

speaker: Roz
text: [_unfazed_] Everything but my bracelets.

speaker: Worth
text: [_laughing_] Yes, sir! _Frasier, shocked, turns away to see Ferguson open the door to a second couple, Ted & Lois._

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, Ted and Lois!  Oh please, come in.

speaker: Lois
text: I hope you don't mind, but we had an extra ticket, so we brought a friend.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, of course, the more the merrier!

speaker: Mel
text: Good evening, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Mel... what a delightful surprise.  I had no idea you knew the Fischers.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, uh, look who's here!

speaker: Niles
text: [_stops dead_] Darling!

speaker: Mel
text: Niles, I didn't think I'd see you here tonight, I thought you were working late... [_sweet_] Oh well, lucky me!

speaker: Niles
text: No, [_kisses her_] lucky me!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_before Daphne can scream_] Lucky all of us!  Please, won't you sit down?

speaker: Niles
text: What, uh - what are you doing here?

speaker: Mel
text: Look, I didn't know we were stopping by here on our way, so just put on your party face and deal with it.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I'm sorry, I have plans.

speaker: Mel
text: Yes, you do - to be by your wife's side.

speaker: Frasier
text: Everybody good?  Everybody happy?  Let's try to respect the feelings and long-held dreams of others.

speaker: Mel
text: Don't worry, Frasier, everything's going to be fine.

speaker: Frasier
text: "Fine?"  Fine for whom?  Is that code, what does that mean?!

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne, Daphne, I'm so sorry.  Listen, this party can't last more than an hour, after that we'll have the whole evening together, I promise.

speaker: Daphne
text: Please don't make any more promises you can't keep.

speaker: Mel
text: Oh, Niles!  Come over here and listen to Tedd's funny joke about communists in heaven!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I'm laughing already!  _He goes over to Mel.  DISSOLVE TO: Later.  Near the kitchen, Murchie is standing with Frasier._

speaker: Murchie
text: Frasier, this party is a triumph!  I shouldn't be telling you this, but if my straw poll is any indication, we may be seeing you at the next board meeting.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh well, I-I hope you don't think that's why I did this! But it's certainly a nice fringe benefit.

speaker: Murchie
text: [_amused_] I'm no farmer, Crane, but I can smell manure a mile away.  You'll be a welcome addition.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Ferguson, Ferguson, listen, make sure that everyone has champagne.  I have a little toast in mind that I daresay will seal the deal. _Nearby, Todd and Lois are chatting with Niles and Mel.  Daphne, whom Frasier has conscripted to serve hors d'oeuvres, is forced to stand right in front of them and play the mute serving girl._

speaker: Ted
text: By the by, don't make any plans for New Year's Eve.  Lo and I are having a blowout at our Mercer Island Place.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, that's a very generous offer, but, uh-

speaker: Mel
text: Oh, we'd love to.  It'll give you a chance to wear that new Valentino I might be getting you- _Daphne, unable to take any more, puts down the tray and runs to her room, passing Ferguson._

speaker: Ferguson
text: Miss Moon?

speaker: Niles
text: Uh, Mel, may I see you for a moment?

speaker: Mel
text: Uh, well actually I-

speaker: Niles
text: Yeah, thank you, thank you, excuse us, excuse us, just one second. _He drags her into the kitchen, where Ferguson is refilling the glasses. Ferguson sees them and makes a hasty exit._

speaker: Niles
text: New Year's Eve with you?  Are you out of your mind?

speaker: Mel
text: Keep your voice down!

speaker: Niles
text: Look, I have gone along with this charade because I hurt you, but now you're just dragging it out to be vindictive.  I'm not going to tolerate it any longer.

speaker: Mel
text: Oh, really?  And what are you going to do about it?

speaker: Niles
text: Keep pushing me, you'll find out.

speaker: Mel
text: Don't threaten me.  You made a promise, and you're going to keep it! _In the living room, Ferguson brings an armful of coats and wraps to the guests._

speaker: Ferguson
text: [_handing Diane her wrap_] Your wrap, madam, Dr. Crane thanks you for coming...

speaker: Frasier
text: Ferguson, Ferguson, what in blue blazes are you doing?

speaker: Ferguson
text: Perhaps to spare you some embarrassment, sir, I took the liberty.

speaker: Frasier
text: Stop!  You're taking far too much liberty with the liberty- taking!  Please, just see that everyone has some champagne.

speaker: Ferguson
text: [_obeying_] Sir. _He replaces the coats, and Frasier calls for attention and raises his glass._

speaker: Frasier
text: There's no need to leave.  Uh, I would like to propose a toast...

speaker: Niles
text: No Mel, why don't you listen for once?  I'm through!

speaker: Mel
text: _I'll_ tell you when you're through, you spineless twit, AND YOU'RE NOT EVEN CLOSE!!! _Frasier runs to the light switch and frantically flicks it on and off, like the house lights at an intermission._

speaker: Frasier
text: Opera time, opera time!  On to the show! _To no avail.  Everyone's attention is on the kitchen -- including Daphne, who has entered from her room just in time to see Mel storm out of the kitchen, followed by Niles._

speaker: Niles
text: That's it, Mel, I'm sick of these games!

speaker: Mel
text: Niles, don't make a scene.

speaker: Niles
text: I don't care!  I love Daphne, and I'm not putting her through this torture another second!  This sham of a marriage is OVER! _Angle on Daphne: "And the trumpets sounded for her on the other side..."  For a moment, there is a standoff.  Then everyone from the board rushes to comfort Mel._

speaker: Diane
text: It's all right, dear, we've known for some time he doesn't deserve you.

speaker: Mel
text: Well, you've seen what I have to put up with.  I've tried so hard, I really have.

speaker: Lois
text: I don't know how you've put up with him this long.

speaker: Mel
text: I just want out.

speaker: Ted
text: Don't worry, I'll handle the divorce papers personally!  This jackass will be out of your life by the end of the week!

speaker: Niles
text: You mean it? _Everyone leaves.  Before he goes, Alan gives Frasier an amused look that spells doom to his prospects for a board seat._

speaker: Murchie
text: See you around, Crane.

speaker: Daphne
text: I love you, too.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, come on, Frasier, you don't want to spend the evening with those snobs anyway.

speaker: Worth
text: Coming, Roz?

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah, I'll be right there.

speaker: Roz
text: [_off everyone's looks_] I'm just getting an early start on the candy drive.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I'm-I'm sorry I ruined your evening.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's all right, Niles.  It's a small price to pay to finally see you and Daphne together.

speaker: Niles
text: It's true - we're free! [_Daphne laughs_] No more hiding! Where do you want to go?  Dinner?  Dancing?  London?  Paris?

speaker: Daphne
text: Why don't we go for a walk?

speaker: Niles
text: Even better.

speaker: Ferguson
text: If you'll allow me.

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you, Ferguson.

speaker: Ferguson
text: My pleasure, sir.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_with all her heart_] Thank you, Ferguson.

speaker: Ferguson
text: It was my privilege, Miss Moon.

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, Ferguson, we got some fences to mend with the board.  What do we send and to whom do we send it?

speaker: Ferguson
text: Actually, sir, I regret to inform you that I must tender my resignation.

speaker: Frasier
text: Please, don't be upset that things didn't go so well this evening.  I'll make it up to you - send yourself something!

speaker: Ferguson
text: Thank you, sir, but it's not you.  It was your brother and Miss Moon.  His willingness to break social rank has inspired me.  And there's a certain Lady Westerfield whose acquaintance I'd like to renew.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah.  True love and all that.  Well, [_extends his hand_] good luck, Ferguson.

speaker: Ferguson
text: [_shakes it_] Thank you, sir.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, if you'll excuse me, I've had rather a difficult evening. Think I'll just go take a sad soak in the tub.

speaker: Ferguson
text: Sir, after such an evening, it's not right for a man to draw his own bath.  So, if I may take the liberty...

speaker: Frasier
text: Carry on, Ferguson. _Ferguson bows and goes to the bathroom.  Frasier lets out a wistful sigh._
